title: CBS Cuts Ties With Executives Amid Allegations of Hostile Workplace
summary: Top executives David Friend and Peter Dunn had been suspended in January after Los Angeles Times report. CBS has parted ways with top executives in its television station group amid an investigation into their conduct, the company said Wednesday.

title: Global IT Spending Expected to Rise 8.4% to $4.1 Trillion This Year
summary: Rebound to pre-pandemic spending levels won't spread evenly across industries. Chief information officers and other corporate technology leaders are moving on from stopgap information technology measures deployed during the coronavirus pandemic and eyeing more ambitious projects, according to the latest IT spending forecast by research and consulting firm Gartner Inc.

title: Credit-Card Startup Petal Hires New Chief Compliance Officer
summary: Elizabeth Corbett, who has held senior roles at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, joins the fintech company as it looks for help navigating regulatory issues in Washington. Credit-card startup Petal Card Inc. has hired Elizabeth Corbett, who once worked as a senior official at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, as its new general counsel and chief compliance officer, the company said on Wednesday.

title: New York Taxes Go Skyscraper High
summary: A weak and desperate Cuomo caves to the left on everything.. Amid a Covid-caused urban exodus, with many workers unsure about going back to their Manhattan offices, the best and brightest of Albany have decided to crank up taxes on business, while also raising the income taxes paid by New York City residents to the nation's highest rate. Welcome to the latest episode of progressives gone wild.

title: The Permanent Housing Crisis
summary: Continuing government bans on eviction and foreclosure are doing more harm than good.. One problem with government emergency actions is that the political class never wants them to end. Witness the Biden Administration's extension of the eviction and foreclosure moratoriums, which by now are creating more trouble than they're worth.

title: Why Are Home Prices Soaring?
summary: One reason is a tariff on Canadian lumber that Biden can kill.. Housing prices are climbing across the country, and the cause is more than soaring demand. One overlooked culprit is a lumber shortage made worse by a U.S. tariff on imports from Canada.

title: Woman Versus the Union Machine
summary: Suing Oregon and the SEIU to vindicate her right not to pay fees.. Most readers probably assume that when the U.S. Supreme Court rules, people follow the law. But there was massive resistance in the South to Brown v. Board of Education in the 1950s, and in recent years unions have done everything they can to evade the Court's 2018 Janus v. Afscme ruling that mandatory union fees for government workers violate the First Amendment.

title: Suspected China Hack of Microsoft Shows Signs of Prior Reconnaissance
summary: Investigators suspect personal data taken in earlier huge hacks or scraped off social-media sites aided breach of Microsoft Exchange Server. Microsoft Corp. and U.S. government officials are still working to understand how a network of suspected Chinese hacking groups carried out an unusually indiscriminate and far-reaching cyberattack on Microsoft email software, more than a month after the discovery of an operation that rendered hundreds of thousands of small businesses, schools and other organizations vulnerable to intrusion.

title: Justice Breyer Lays Out Opposition to Expanding Supreme Court
summary: He says restructuring court would be perceived as politicizing it. WASHINGTON-Justice Stephen Breyer said proposals to restructure the Supreme Court could damage its reputation as an apolitical body, dealing a blow to progressives pressing to increase the number of justices to counter Republican successes in seating three members nominated by former President Donald Trump.

title: Marin County's Discriminatory 'Universal Basic Income'
summary: Only 'mothers of color' will be eligible for payments of $1,000 a month.. Some 125 residents in Marin County, Calif., can expect to begin receiving payments of $1,000 a month starting in May-no strings attached. It's an experiment providing a "universal basic income," or UBI, to low-income Americans.

title: CEOs' Selective Virtue Signaling
summary: If executives oppose restrictive voting laws, why are they singling out Georgia?. Major League Baseball Commissioner Robert D. Manfred Jr. will regret his decision to move the All-Star Game from Atlanta in response to Georgia's new election laws. He's dropped his sport into a red-hot controversy, based on imaginary facts and flawed assertions.

title: To Counter Beijing, Send In the Coast Guard
summary: China exploits ambiguity at sea, and the service could be a vital part of the effort to keep the peace.. As Washington looks to counter Beijing's ambitions, one good idea is to unleash the U.S. Coast Guard, which could and should play a larger role in preserving order in the Pacific. The recent appearance of a 200-ship Chinese "fishing" flotilla in the South China Sea, loitering in Beijing-claimed waters and intimidating regional states, shows the urgency of addressing China's maritime predations.

title: Teddy Roosevelt's Advice for Those Who Get College Rejections
summary: Words of wisdom for the student in the arena.. High-school seniors across America are hearing back from the colleges and universities to which they applied. Many weren't accepted by their first choice. To them I commend Theodore Roosevelt's "man in the arena" speech.

title: 'High Conflict' Review: When Push Comes to Shove
summary: Interpersonal discord is a normal part of human life. Sometimes we're drawn into stupid and destructive forms of conflict. Why?. Amanda Ripley, a journalist whose first book, "The Unthinkable," was about how people survive disasters, has covered "all manner of human misery." Her latest book, "High Conflict: Why We Get Trapped and How We Get Out," is prompted by misery of the American political kind. After the 2016 election, Ms. Ripley reflects, journalists who cared about telling the truth in all its complexity were preaching to a "shrinking choir of partisans." Those who still read the news searched it for weapons to use against enemies. It "felt like curiosity was dead."

title: Yes, Boycott Baseball
summary: Liberals the past year have become addicted to political wokeness. It's time for an intervention. Sherman's burning of Atlanta wasn't enough punishment. title: Ron DeSantis and 'Resistance Journalism'
summary: Florida's governor and the new rules of media sourcing.. It's hard to find silver linings in this era of expanding government authority and contracting individual opportunity for free expression. But at least the media establishment can no longer pretend that its abandonment of journalistic standards was necessitated by the unique character of Donald Trump. "Resistance journalism" is now industry standard, judging by a story on Florida's Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis by the formerly prestigious television newsmagazine "60 Minutes."

title: The Political Battle Over Poland's Holocaust History

This somber day is a reminder that we are rapidly approaching the moment when the Holocaust will become entirely an artifact of history, no longer preserved in the living memory of survivors. It is perhaps no accident that the dying off of the generation of survivors has been accompanied by a disturbing resurgence of anti-Semitism and a new willingness on the part of political leaders to openly politicize Holocaust history.

title: This NFL Superstar Wants to Host 'Jeopardy!' Full Time
summary: Who is Aaron Rodgers? And could the Packers quarterback pull off a football/game show double life?. He's pretty good at it, right away, which feels a little preposterous. It should be enough that Aaron Rodgers is one of the great quarterbacks of all time, a Super Bowl champion and three-time NFL MVP who can still, at age 37, scramble from linemen and sling a football at uncanny angles for amazing distances, and now, it turns out, he can also do this, too, host the most prestigious TV game show there is, not as expertly as the late, great Alex Trebek, but capably, like he might be born to do this, too.

title: Got Your Covid-19 Vaccine? Now Cancel Your Extra Appointments
summary: Pharmacies and community clinics say uncanceled appointments lead to no-shows, adding to their already heavy workload. Pharmacies and health officials are making a plea to Americans who received their Covid-19 vaccines: Cancel the other shots you booked.

title: The Anxiety of Getting Back into Beauty Routines
summary: In terms of grooming, the pandemic has been a year of rest and relaxation for many people. But as society reopens, there's pressure to resume the beauty regimens we once maintained.. "Why is your hair that way.... It looks fancy?" It was a question 4-year-old Bodie posed recently to his mom, New Jersey-based publicist Jaime Maser, 42, who, after many months of haphazard buns or ponytails, had blown out her hair. Pre-pandemic, blowouts were a regular occurrence for Maser, along with hair color appointments every three weeks, monthly gel manicures and a Botox refresh every few months. While Maser has slowly started to reinstate some of those beauty rituals, she doesn't see herself going back to her former level of maintenance now that the world has, in her words, shifted on its axis. "I've started to embrace the ease of spending less time and money and energy going from place to place for my assorted beauty services," she says.

title: Self-Driving Cars May Be Too Speculative Even for This Market
summary: Autonomous driving remains an unproven technology, but trucks have a better commercial case than robotaxis as startups sound out stock investors. Driverless-vehicle ventures are starting to go public, in what looks to be the ultimate test of stock investors' preference for long-range vision over near-term profits.

title: New York City's Deadliest Day From Covid-19 Hit One Year Ago
summary: Resume Subscription. In early March of last year, Jorge Morales was keeping customers caffeinated at Mike's Coffee Express, a popular roadside food truck near LaGuardia Airport in Queens that he ran for more than 30 years.

title: Biden Rule on Covid-19 Workplace Safety Misses Deadline
summary: Proponents say order is needed now as economy more fully reopens, while opponents say widespread vaccine availability eliminates need. Hundreds of thousands of Americans are returning to work but without the federal Covid-19 workplace safety rules the Biden administration wanted released by mid-March.

title: Chip Shortage Fuels $100 Billion Dream
summary: Semiconductor-equipment stocks have soared this year on spending hopes, but Applied Materials is playing it safe with its forecast. When will the market for semiconductor manufacturing equipment reach $100 billion a year? Inquiring minds want to know.

title: The Dollar Bond Binge Will Come Home to Roost Even Without a Blow-Up
summary: Emerging markets are less at risk of a sudden seizure in their ability to refinance their debts, but large amounts of bonds coming due will squeeze them over time. The U.S. economy is roaring ahead of its peers, with growth estimates still being upgraded by the International Monetary Fund. But a more rapid U.S. expansion will have inevitable knock-on effects for the burgeoning pile of U.S. dollar-denominated debt issued by foreign governments and companies in the last decade, even if that takes time to feed through.

title: Shell Warns Oil-Price Gains Partly Offset by Hit From Texas Freeze
summary: Energy giant says higher oil prices will buoy first-quarter results but Texas weather caused $200 million hit. LONDON-Royal Dutch Shell PLC said gains it made from higher oil prices in the first quarter would be partly offset by disruption related to the winter storm in Texas, knocking the energy giant's recovery from the pandemic.

title: Stephen Miller's Next Act Finds a Stage in the Courts
summary: Trump senior adviser-and conservative lightning rod-launches new legal group to challenge Democratic policies through lawsuits. WASHINGTON-Stephen Miller has come to admire the effectiveness-and aggressiveness-of the legal campaign Democrats and their supporters mounted against the Trump administration's agenda.

title: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon Sees 'Goldilocks Moment' for U.S. Economy
summary: Stimulus, infrastructure spending and vaccines could fuel an economic boom into 2023, he tells shareholders in his annual letter. The leader of America's biggest bank said the U.S. economy is emerging from the coronavirus pandemic into a boom that could last until 2023.

title: Intel Backs Video Data Firm Offering an Ad-Targeting Alternative to Cookies
summary: Iris.TV, which has raised an $18 million Series B, provides information on video content to allow marketers to target ads based on contextual relevance. Intel Capital, the investment arm of Intel Corp., has led a new $18 million Series B investment round in Iris.TV Inc., a data technology company that provides tools to help marketers and others understand the content of individual videos for the purposes of ad targeting and measurement.

title: China's Sportswear Giants Enjoy Big Market Run-Up
summary: The Hong Kong-traded shares of both Anta and Li Ning have more than doubled in the past 12 months. Investors are betting that China's two biggest sportswear companies will emerge from the pandemic even stronger.

title: George Floyd's Family: What It Is Like to Watch the Trial
summary: From the courtroom or a private viewing room, the family sees the video footage again, observes the jury. MINNEAPOLIS-As a jury watched video footage of George Floyd's death, his family members watched along with them in the Minneapolis courthouse where the former police officer charged in his death is being tried.

title: What Amazon's Alabama Union Vote Means for the Company and Workers
summary: Bessemer employees would be the only unionized Amazon workers in a nation where memberships have dwindled. If workers at an Amazon.com facility in Bessemer, Ala., vote to unionize, it would boost the number of workers who have opted to join a union in a state that has membership rates below the U.S. average.

title: Fed's Kaplan Says the Economy Still Needs Central Bank Support
summary: The Dallas Fed chief also says reducing stimulus when the pandemic abates and more economic progress is made will help keep the recovery going. Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan said it isn't time for the central bank to pull back on its support of the economy, but paring stimulus when it becomes clear the coronavirus pandemic is abating and the economy is meeting the Fed's goals will be important to keep the recovery on track.

title: Transcript: WSJ Interview With Dallas Fed President Robert Kaplan
summary: Resume Subscription. Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan discussed why he has signaled, but not promised, support for an interest-rate increase next year in an interview with The Wall Street Journal's Michael S. Derby on Tuesday. The central banker also talked about his views on risk taking in markets and its relationship to monetary policy, why climate change issues are a key part of his work, and what China's new digital currency might mean for the U.S. Here is a transcript, lightly edited for clarity.

title: Tennis Star Sloane Stephens Brings Her Competitive Ethos to Startup Investing
summary: The 2017 U.S. Open champion, who is backing an energy-bar startup, says she has high hopes for companies owned by women of color. Professional tennis player Sloane Stephens has joined the ranks of professional athletes investing in startups, backing caffeine-infused energy bar maker Quantum Energy Squares.

title: Ship Thought to Be Spying for Iran Is Attacked in Red Sea
summary: Vessel has been off the western coast of Yemen since early 2017, several officials say. An Iranian ship thought to be used by Iran's elite military force was attacked Tuesday near Saudi-Yemeni waters, both U.S. and Iranian officials said, in an apparent escalation of a conflict between Iran and its regional foes.

title: Toshiba Considers Buyout Offer
summary: Toshiba said it would seek more details from CVC Capital Partners. Japan's Toshiba Corp. said Wednesday that it received a proposal for acquisition from private-equity firm CVC Capital Partners , in a deal that could be valued at more than $20 billion if completed.

title: Biden Says All U.S. Adults Should Be Eligible for Vaccine by April 19
summary: President says U.S. has surpassed 150 million shots since he took office. WASHINGTON-President Biden said Tuesday that all U.S. adults should be eligible for Covid-19 vaccines by April 19, speeding up a timeline he set out last month, and he urged Americans to be patient and take precautions as the rollout continued and new variants spread.

title: BlackRock Must Hit ESG Targets or Pay More to Borrow Money
summary: The money manager and its lenders tied costs around a $4.4 billion credit facility to BlackRock's diversity and sustainability goals. Investment giant BlackRock Inc. will need to hit its staff-diversity targets and other sustainable-business goals to keep its corporate borrowing costs down.

title: Samsung Expects Operating Profit Rose 44% in First Quarter
summary: South Korean company beats expectations during global shortage of semiconductors and despite shutdowns of some U.S. facilities. Samsung Electronics Co. said it expects a 44% increase in operating profit for the first quarter, topping expectations during a global shortage of semiconductors and despite shutdowns of some U.S. chip-making facilities.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription.

title: Netanyahu Given Another Try at Forming a Government
summary: Israel's longest-serving leader is given the mandate to assemble a coalition after an inconclusive election.

title: Ivy League Acceptance Rates Fall to Record Lows Due to Covid-19
summary: Harvard accepts just 3.4% of applicants, while Columbia admitted 3.7%. A pandemic-fueled surge in applications translated into record low acceptance rates this year for the country's elite colleges, including most of the Ivy League.

title: Bezos Backs Corporate Tax-Rate Increase and Infrastructure Plan
summary: Amazon CEO's support comes amid criticism of the company's low tax rates and workplace policies. Amazon . com Inc. Chief Executive Jeff Bezos said he supports a rise in the corporate tax rate and supports President Biden's focus on major U.S. infrastructure spending.

title: Longtime Congressman Alcee Hastings Dies at 84
summary: Democrat was first Black federal judge in Florida but was impeached and removed from federal bench before being elected to House. Rep. Alcee Hastings has died, his office said Tuesday, after the longtime congressman was diagnosed two years ago with pancreatic cancer.

title: Former Gunvor Employee Pleads Guilty in Ecuadorean Bribery Scheme
summary: Raymond Kohut pleads guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit money laundering. A former employee of European energy trader Gunvor Group Ltd. pleaded guilty to participating in a bribery scheme involving Ecuador's state-controlled oil company.
